title: Getting the rights for Keen back into Tom Hall's possession!
content:
Something just occurred to me.

Tom Hall can't get the rights to his creation (Commander Keen) because iD still think that they can squeeze some juice out of it.
They probably think this because Keen was so popular back in the day and has endured the test of time to still have some popularity today.

So, maybe simply by keeping the popularity of Keen alive, we, the Keeners, are ruining Mr Hall's chances of ever getting the rights back! Perhaps only when iD think that Keen's popularity has run dry will they toss Keen aside for Tom Hall to reclaim, if indeed he is still alive by that stage.

So I present you with this suggestion:

[img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-mortlol.gif[/img] JOIN ME AND MY TEAM OF ANTI-KEEN VIGILANTES AS WE SHUT DOWN NOT ONLY THE PCKF, BUT ALSO EVERY KEEN FAN SITE ON THE INTERNET. LIKEWISE WE WILL DO OUR DARNEDEST TO WIPE OUT EVERY FORM OF KEEN CULTURE SUCH AS FANART, KEEN GAME DOWNLOADS, AND BANDS WITH NAMES LIKE "COMMANDER KEEN". KEEN CANNOT BE REBORN UNTIL HE HAS BEEN SCRUBBED OUT ENTIRELY. IF YOU LOVE KEEN, YOU WILL WIPE HIM OUT. ALL OF HIM.

AS A MATTER OF FACT, WE HAVE BEEN DOING THIS FOR NEARLY TEN YEARS NOW; THE DECLINE OF THE PCKF IS DUE TO OUR EFFORTS, AS IS THE WANING POPULARITY OF KEEN ITSELF. IT WAS EVEN ONE OF OUR OWN AGENTS WHO WAS BEHIND THE CRAPPY GAMEBOY VERSION OF KEEN, INTENTIONALLY CRAPPY SO AS TO MAKE KEEN EVEN LESS POPULAR.

JOIN US IN OUR QUEST AND SAVE COMMANDER KEEN!




So, pretty crazy idea huh? Crazy enough to work! Who's with me?

















Guys? [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-mortvort.gif[/img]

----------
www.StrifeStrips.com! Woot! We're back, baby!

title: Re: re:
content:
In the music industry, if a publisher fails to exploit a copyright, that usually constitutes a breach of agreement, and it is pretty easy for the creator of that copyright to sue the publisher and get the rights back.

What ID is doing to Keen (pretending he doesn't exist for a decade and a half) would constitute failure to exploit.

What kind of agreement is there between ID and Tom Hall? Is it like a publishing agreement? Or does ID own the rights, lock stock and barrel? (In the music industry, the latter arrangement is practically unheard of post-1960's. But I guess the game industry is probably different.)

title: Re: re:
content:
Truth be told, I suppose no one other than Tom and iD know the full story.

Well, I'm going to (or Neeksoft is going to) send an email to iD very soon.

title: Re: Getting the rights for Keen back into Tom Hall's possess

[quote]Quote:[hr]
Originally posted by kohntarkosz:

In the music industry, if a publisher fails to exploit a copyright, that usually constitutes a breach of agreement, and it is pretty easy for the creator of that copyright to sue the publisher and get the rights back.[hr][/quote]

Is what you're saying similar to abandonware?

title: Re: Getting the rights for Keen back into Tom Hall's possess
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]Is what you're saying similar to abandonware? [hr][/quote]

Not really. "Abandonware" implies that an old copyright is no longer valid - this is not the case. The copyright to Commander Keen will still be valid for seventy years after the copyright-owner dies.

What's at question here is who that copyright-owner is.

title: Re: Getting the rights for Keen back into Tom Hall's possess
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]Hm, I wonder if there's anything goverment styled thing that'd keep record of who owns and what. It'd make sense if there were... How otherwise could it be? No idea if
there is, though. [hr][/quote]

Copyrights are agreements between parties, and it's each party's job to keep track of the agreements. The government's job is to set and enforce the rules.

Copyrights are like bicycles: there is no central government agency that keeps tabs on every bicycle in the country, but if someone steals your bike you can call a cop and try to get it back.

I suppose, if someone not previously involved with either Hall or ID were REALLY interested in exposing the dispute to the light of day, one could attempt to make money off a Keen product and see if Hall sues you first or if ID sues you first. Still interested?[img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-wink.gif[/img]
